meta.title: Food, drug, and other allergy testing

content:
Introduction

Allergy testing is used to identify immune-mediated hypersensitivity to substances such as foods, medications, contact allergens, and aeroallergens.  These tests vary based on the immunologic mechanism (eg, IgE mediated, T-cell mediated), the type of allergen, and the clinical context.  Accurate testing facilitates the diagnosis and guides avoidance strategies; in addition, it can identify drugs that are unnecessarily on a patient's medication allergy list.

Immune mechanisms of allergic reactions



Four types of hypersensitivity reactions exist.  Types I (IgE mediated, as in anaphylactic food allergy) and IV (T-cell mediated, as in allergic contact dermatitis) can be evaluated via allergy testing, in contrast to types II (IgG- or IgM-autoantibody mediated, as in hemolytic anemia) and III (immune-complex mediated, as in serum sickness).

Immediate hypersensitivity (type I)



Type I hypersensitivity is also called immediate reaction because of its rapid onset (eg, minutes) following exposure to an allergen.  Examples include anaphylactic food allergy, penicillin allergy, venom allergies (eg, wasps, bees, fire ants), latex allergy, acute urticaria, allergic asthma, and seasonal allergies.



The mechanism of type I hypersensitivity involves the production of antigen-specific IgE by B cells that bind mast cell surfaces.  If repeat exposure occurs, the bound IgE can cross-link and stimulate the release of preformed histamine via mast cell degranulation (

Cutaneous type 1 hypersensitivity reaction
).  When the allergen is exposed through the skin, superficial dermal edema and erythema (eg, wheal-and-flare reaction) result within minutes and can progress to a more systemic response (eg, anaphylaxis) (
image 1
).  This wheal-and-flare reaction is what is detected in skin allergy testing (see later section).



A late-phase, type I hypersensitivity reaction sometimes occurs hours later, manifesting as a palpable, indurated lesion due to tissue damage caused by substances released by eosinophils (also as a downstream effect of IgE).  This lesion is not measured in skin allergy testing.

T-cell mediated hypersensitivity (type IV)



Unlike immediate hypersensitivity, delayed reactions take 48-72 hours to manifest.  Allergic contact dermatitis (eg, poison ivy dermatitis) is a classic example.  Certain rare drug reactions (eg, Stevens-Johnson syndrome [SJS], toxic epidermal necrolysis [TEN], drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome, DRESS syndrome [Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms]) are primarily mediated by T cells and are considered type IV reactions.



Type IV (delayed-type) hypersensitivity reaction occurs in 2 distinct phases (

figure 2
):



  1. The sensitization phase leads to the creation of hapten-specific T cells and takes 10-14 days.  Cutaneous dendritic cells take up the haptens and express them on major histocompatibility complex class I (MHC-I) and MHC-II molecules as hapten-conjugated peptides.  These dendritic cells travel to the draining lymph nodes and interact with hapten-sensitive CD4+ and CD8+ T cells, causing activation and clonal expansion.
  2. The elicitation phase occurs within 2-3 days following reexposure to the same antigen (or following sensitization after first exposure to a highly antigenic antigen such as urushiol in poison ivy).  In this phase, the hapten is taken up by skin cells and activates hapten-sensitized T cells in the dermis and epidermis.  This results in an inflammatory response and the clinical manifestations of contact dermatitis (eg, vesicles, erythematous papules) (
    image 2
    ).

Allergy tests overview

Tests for type I hypersensitivity reactions



  • Skin prick testing (SPT), intradermal allergy testing (IAT).
  • Serum-specific IgE testing, serum component-resolved diagnostics (CRDs).
  • Oral food challenge (OFC).
  • Graded drug challenge and drug provocation testing.

Tests for type IV hypersensitivity reactions



  • Patch testing on the skin.


Each of these types of tests is discussed in greater detail below.

Skin prick testing

Method and application



With SPT, allergen extracts are applied and introduced into the epidermis via a pricking device to identify allergen-specific IgE on cutaneous mast cells (type I hypersensitivity reactions).  SPT tests for aeroallergens and environmental allergens such as pollens (trees, grasses, weeds), molds, dust mites, animal dander (eg, cat, dog), and cockroaches.  It also tests various foods (eg, egg, milk, nuts, seafood) and penicillin, which is the only drug approved for SPT.  Although SPT can be used for testing other drugs (eg, amoxicillin, cephalosporins, carboplatin), its negative predictive value is diminished.



SPT is typically performed to confirm a suspected allergic reaction based on history (eg, development of urticaria after an insect sting); it should not be performed for screening purposes.

Result interpretation



  • A positive test indicates sensitization and is generally defined as a wheal that is equal to or larger than the control and that develops within 15-20 minutes.  Sensitization must be accompanied by a history of allergic symptoms to establish that the compound causes an allergic reaction.  Isolated sensitization without a history of allergic symptoms does not equate with the patient being allergic to the compound.
  • A negative test has high negative predictive value (eg, 95%), indicating that the patient is highly unlikely to be sensitized to the compound.

Contraindications



  • Poorly controlled asthma or a history of anaphylaxis (due to potential poor outcome).
  • Active urticaria and cutaneous mastocytosis (due to false-positive results).
  • Recent intake (eg, <2-5 days) of H1 and H2 antihistamines (due to false-negative results).
  • Topical corticosteroid therapy (due to false-negative results).
  • Dermatitis (eg, atopic dermatitis).

Intradermal allergy testing

Method and application



With IAT, allergens are injected into the dermis (vs the epidermis in SPT) with a syringe.  Like SPT, IAT identifies allergen-specific IgE on cutaneous mast cells (type I hypersensitivity reactions).  Compared to SPT, IAT is more sensitive and is therefore typically performed following a negative SPT.  IAT's greater sensitivity makes it more useful for venom and drug testing.

Result interpretation



  • A positive test indicates sensitization and is generally defined as a wheal â‰¥5 mm that develops within 15-20 minutes.  Sensitization must be accompanied by allergic symptoms to be considered an allergic reaction; isolated sensitization without a history of allergic symptoms does not equate with the patient being allergic to the compound.
  • A negative test has high negative predictive value, indicating that the patient is highly unlikely to be allergic to the compound.

Contraindications



In addition to the contraindications of SPT, IAT is contraindicated when food or latex allergy is suspected due to high rates of anaphylaxis with IAT.

Serum-specific IgE testing

Method and application



Serum-specific IgE testing is a blood test that identifies allergen-specific IgE in the blood.  It is used to evaluate type I hypersensitivity reactions caused by food, venom, environmental (eg, pollens, molds, dust mites, cockroaches, animal allergens), latex, and certain occupational allergens; in contrast, its use in drug allergy testing is largely investigational.  It relies on enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, fluorescent enzyme immunoassay, or other immunoassay techniques.



Unlike SPT and IAT, serum-specific IgE testing does not introduce allergens to the patient, which makes it an attractive option in a patient with a history of anaphylaxis.  In addition, it is preferred in patients with dermatitis or dermatographism and is not affected by medication intake (eg, H1 and H2 antihistamines).

Result interpretation



  • An elevated IgE level against a specific allergen suggests sensitization and increases the likelihood of clinical allergic symptoms.  However, an elevated IgE level against a specific allergen alone without a history of allergic symptoms to that allergen does not indicate that the patient is allergic to the allergen.
  • A negative result could indicate a lack of sensitization, but it could also indicate that the patient has not been exposed to the allergen recently (eg, within weeks).  After allergen exposure, serum IgE rises; however, the half-life of circulating IgE is 48 hours before it attaches to mast cells, making these IgE undetectable via serum testing.  A negative result should generally be followed by skin testing if there are no contraindications.

Contraindications



There are no contraindications; however, the test is more expensive than skin testing and tends to have lower sensitivity and specificity overall compared to skin testing.

Serum component-resolved diagnostics

Method and application



CRD is a blood test done in specialized laboratories.  In contrast to serum-specific IgE testing, which detects IgE associated with the whole allergen, CRD tests for IgE that binds specific antigenic epitopes; this allows differentiation between IgE against clinically irrelevant allergens and IgE against allergens that carry a high anaphylaxis risk.  Therefore, CRD risk stratifies the patient and offers important prognostic information.



For example, CRD can identify IgE that binds multiple epitopes on several peanut proteins:



  • Ara h 2 protein is strongly associated with anaphylaxis.
  • Ara h 8 protein is linked to oral allergy syndrome, a localized allergic reaction that is typically limited to throat pruritus without systemic symptoms and that is due to cross-reactivity between Ara h 8 and birch pollen.


In practice, a serum-specific IgE test may show a general sensitivity toward peanuts, whereas CRD risk stratifies the patient based on whether the IgE is against Ara h 2 or Ara h 8.



Given the cross-reactivity between birch pollen and Ara h 8, patients with isolated Ara h 8 sensitization and a known history of birch pollen allergy may undergo an OFC test (discussed later); if limited (eg, throat pruritus) or no symptoms develop, patients may generally be reassured that they may eat peanuts.  In contrast, a patient with IgE against Ara h 2 on component testing is at high risk for anaphylaxis and should avoid peanuts.

Result interpretation



This is discussed in the previous Method and Application section.

Contraindications



Although not a contraindication, component testing is not indicated in patients who can easily avoid a food that is not typically a part of their regular diet.

Oral food challenge

Method and application



OFC is the gold standard for diagnosing or refuting a food allergy.  It is also used to determine whether a previous food allergy has been resolved.  Most commonly, it is used to confirm tolerance when SPT and/or serum IgE testing are negative in a patient with a questionable history of allergic reaction to a particular food.



The patient ingests increasing doses of the suspected food under supervision, typically over 4-6 steps.  The patient is observed for 15 minutes after each dose for type I hypersensitivity reactions (eg, hives, vomiting, diarrhea) before a higher dose is introduced.

Result interpretation



  • Type I hypersensitivity reaction at any time during the test indicates food allergy.
  • Tolerance of a meal-sized portion of the food refutes food allergy.

Contraindications



OFC should be avoided when anaphylaxis has occurred after isolated ingestion of a food and when IgE in vitro testing is positive for that food.  An OFC will likely precipitate another anaphylactic reaction.

Graded drug challenge and drug provocation testing

Method and application



These tests are used primarily to confirm that penicillin is tolerated when skin testing for penicillin is negative.  Other drugs (eg, sulfamethoxazole, fluoroquinolones, macrolides, tetracyclines) can also be used in these tests.



The tests involve incremental administration of the drug, typically beginning at 1/100 to 1/10 of the therapeutic dose and progressing through multiple steps until a full dose is reached.

Result interpretation



Type I hypersensitivity is refuted if the patient tolerates the therapeutic dose without signs of an allergic reaction.

Contraindications



These tests should be avoided with drugs that may have caused SJS, TEN, erythema multiforme, and hypersensitivity reactions involving internal organs (eg, DRESS syndrome).

Patch testing

Method and application



Patch testing consists of applying patches of allergenic compounds to the skin (eg, back) for a specified time (usually 48 hr) to allow allergen penetration.  It is used primarily to identify allergens in allergic contact dermatitis (type IV hypersensitivity reaction), particularly when it is chronic, recalcitrant, or recurrent.  It can also be used to exclude concomitant allergic contact dermatitis in patients with known chronic irritant contact dermatitis.

Result interpretation



The presence of erythema and vesicles (

image 3
) at 48 hours after patch removal indicates that the patient has a delayed-type hypersensitivity toward the compound tested; this compound is identified as an allergen and should be avoided.  (Erythema that is present 15-60 min after patch removal but disappears by 48 hr after removal indicates an irritant reaction that is not allergic in nature.)

Contraindications



  • Avoid testing on inflamed skin (eg, atopic dermatitis).
  • Avoid testing if the patient has recently been taking certain medications (eg, systemic corticosteroid therapy, topical corticosteroid therapy at the test site, certain high-dose immunosuppressive therapy).  Oral antihistamines are not expected to interfere with patch testing because type IV hypersensitivity is T-cell, not histamine, mediated.  (In contrast, antihistamine therapy must be stopped prior to SPT and IAT because these tests evaluate for type I hypersensitivity, which is histamine mediated.)

Examples of clinical applications

Case 1



A child with atopic dermatitis and a history of vomiting after eating eggs tests positive for egg white IgE and has a 6-mm wheal on SPT.  OFC confirms objective symptoms at 1 g of egg protein.  Diagnosis: IgE-mediated egg allergy.

Case 2



An adult reports a childhood penicillin allergy without recall of reaction.  SPT and IAT are negative.  A supervised oral amoxicillin challenge shows no reaction.  Diagnosis: no current penicillin allergy.

Case 3



A florist develops chronic hand eczema.  Patch testing is positive for thiuram mix (rubber) and colophony (plant resin).  Avoidance of rubber gloves and specific plants leads to symptom resolution.  Diagnosis: allergic contact dermatitis.

Case 4



An adult develops allergic conjunctivitis and allergic rhinitis when outdoors during the spring.  Symptoms are generally well controlled with topical antihistamine eye drops and nasal corticosteroid therapy.  The patient inquires about allergy testing to identify specific allergens.  Allergy testing is not recommended because avoiding the likely allergens (eg, pollen) is impractical or impossible; in addition, symptoms are well controlled with medications.

Summary



Allergy testing involves diagnostic tools that identify immune-mediated hypersensitivity to substances such as foods, medications, contact allergens, and aeroallergens.  Allergy testing can be broadly divided into tests that identify type I versus type IV hypersensitivities.



Type I hypersensitivity is IgE mediated and causes allergic asthma, seasonal allergies, food allergy, penicillin allergy, venom allergies (eg, wasps, bees, fire ants), and latex allergy.  IgE-based allergy evaluation includes skin prick testing, intradermal testing, serum-specific IgE testing, and component-resolved diagnostics.  A positive test suggests sensitization but must be accompanied by a history of allergic symptoms to diagnose an allergy to a particular compound.  To definitively confirm tolerance to a food or drug, oral food challenge testing or graded drug challenge testing is performed under supervision.



Type IV hypersensitivity is T-cell mediated and classically causes allergic contact dermatitis (eg, poison ivy dermatitis) and rarer forms of drug allergies (eg, Stevens-Johnson syndrome).  Patch testing is used to identify the culprit allergen in allergic contact dermatitis.
